title: Which presidential candidate will win Virginia?
preds: *This is definitely cheating - would work only in case GJO makes a mistake to include today in the scores (as indicated by resolution date)*
*This is definitely cheating - would work only in case GJO makes a mistake to include today in the scores (as indicated by resolution date)*
Final look at the polls, Clinton being upgraded. Only chance now lies in a significant polling failure in Trump's favour.
Most polls seem to indicate a Clinton victory.

Based on the strong polling numbers, and the general disinterest around the beltway for shaking up DC too much, I show Clinton with a strong edge. However, if I average that with Virginia's historical support of Republicans, I would have to invert that, and give Trump a 63% chance of winning. Since Trump is not a traditional Republican, and it is not in Northern Virginia's interest in seeing the government shaken completely, I'm cautiously sticking with the poll projections - Clinton will win 52% of the votes that matter.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
Virginia is trending from purple to blue at the Presidential level, and from red to purple at the state level.

In the past 5 US elections, Virgina has gone Dem, Dem, Rep, Rep, Rep, with a close race each time. It is a Republican-leaning state historically. That gives us a baseline of 60% Republican. However, Clinton is heavily ahead in polls, with Trump having been ahead in one poll in the last three months. Its demographics are roughly in line with national average, so are unlikely to change the result likelihood. The polls suggest a Clinton win, though the state's history suggest a tighter race than on paper. Polls aren't everything.

It will be extremely close. So close. But, with Obama and Michelle out there campaigning and even with CNN not emphasizing any of the negative news against Hillary, I see that Trump and not going to get what he needs. Yet, like I note it is soooo close. We may have a Gore/Bush year.

Average of 9 Polls
Last Poll: Nov. 4
CLINTON 49%
Trump 43%
Secretary Clinton has a well-executed get-out-the-vote effort; she is strongly supported by the governor; Virginia has been trending Democratic; there is likely to be a large Latino vote.

538 forecast gives Clinton an 80% prob.
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/virginia/ RCP polling average, Clinton leads by 5.2 pts:
http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/va/virginia_trump_vs_clinton_vs_johnson_vs_stein-5966.html
Changing demographics not fully captured in polls.
HRC will have the edge based on the National Capitol Region government employees who see her as ensuring their employment longevity.
Barring the unforeseeable, the Clinton-Kaine ticket is set to win Virginia handily, completing the state's transformation from a light-red state to a light-blue state over the past 12 years.
She is ahead and Tim Kaine adds more strength.
Hillary needs this to get to 270 and if she doesn't win this one she won't.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

Latest polls: 10/27/2016 Quinnipiac: CLINTON 53%, Trump 40%
10/28/2016 Christopher Newport univ.: CLINTON 46% Trump 39%
33 VA polls; probability of leading calculated, then averaged.
Obama won, so Hillary should, but America is mad.
Late polls show that Trump could win Florida.
With a 92.9% probability of winning the State of Virginia handily, Clinton has a "lock" on winning this state, and not just because of her running mate Tim Kane.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
HRC's post-hot-mic/debate polling lead has moved up to the low double digits and time is running out, so I'm bumping up her expectations marginally.
Her polling has been improving. Third debate was solid. Heavy turnout around DC already.

Swing state and she will carry all of them except maybe Ohio
Running mate from Va.

The Wall Street Journal reported that the Trump campaign has pulled out of Virginia.
Most recent polls give Hillary the lead: http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/va/virginia_trump_vs_clinton-5542.html
I hear that Trump has decamped from VA.
Purely on  apprx. 10% lead of Clinton.

In another blow to Trump's campaign on Thursday, Republican sources confirmed that Trump was pulling his resources from Virginia, a state that has seen a huge influx in the number of foreign-born citizens and large growth among Asians, who have increasingly tilted toward Democrats in recent years. (CNN.com)

My Republican friends from VA are aghast. Some, have NEVER voted Democrat. Whether at the end of the day, they vote for Hillary, who knows....it's a secret ballot, but I am sure they won't vote for Trump. VA Republican politics is shooting at itself in the foot (firing of recent campaign manager).  Seth Myers has staked out VA as site for his show this week. The barrage of sharpened arrows are squarely, and hilariously, pointed at The Donald. HRC gets a few, but DT is such a siren call for more, it is hard to hold back the barrage. Plus, it didn't do DT any good to be such a hard-ass sour-puss at the WH Correspondent's dinner roasting. Just an aside...I'm not sure I have ever seen DT actually laugh (YouTube, media video, etc) because something struck him funny.
If Utah is truly in play with 27 days to go, there's no point in being too cute or precise: Virginia is 100%. I will say 99% in deference to the black swan.
Methinks we have seen peak Trump.
Virginia looks pretty safe for HRC; +9 in RCP average http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/va/virginia_trump_vs_clinton-5542.html
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
For the same reason you grab a lifeboat.

Clinton is being placed at ~+8 favorite in recent polls with 49% saying they will vote for her. Trump's highest approval was 46% back in July and has since dropped to 41%. Kaine has a very high approval rating at roughly 50/37 approve
Johnson will pull significant number of votes from Trump on the military bases.
Virginia is Clinton's to lose.  She's held it pretty steadily for months.

Averaging the poll of polls from http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/upshot/presidential-polls-forecast.html?action=click&contentCollection=upshot&region=rank&module=package&version=highlights&contentPlacement=2&pgtype=sectionfront&_r=0
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

Virginia has slowly trended more heavily Democratic in the early 21st century. Its combination of a large, heavily Democratic African American population with a growing number of college-educated suburbanites unlikely to support Trump gives Clinton an edge. Tim Kaine's presence on the ticket probably puts Clinton over the top.
http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-president-winner Looks like Hillary is much more certain to win now than she was before.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

Much better set of numbers with a smaller lead for Hillary and more wins for the Donald on the board.
http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-president-winner Feel the election is tighter than these forecasts suggest, but a clear winner nonetheless.
Down from 84-16 on 12 Aug, now following http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/virginia/
The polls are narrowing, but I believe that Hillary will still squeeze this out. It will be very close, but I believe still a Hillary state.
There are too many political professionals in Boomtown's suburbs whose careers are too disrupted by a possible Trump victory. Pros on the left and right will unite to win Virginia, but not by a lot.
Adjusting my forecast for this state race.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
538 and Upshot are moving.  So am I.
HRC detrioating slightly, keep her at 80
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/virginia/#plus
http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-president-winner
http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/presidential-races/294351-polls-show-tight-races-in-iowa-virginia  The poll results for Clinton vs. Trump in Virginia have tightened somewhat.  They are both relatively unpopular in this state - with similar unfavorable ratings.

Clinton has been leading Virginia right from the early polls, consistently by between 5 and 10 %pts. So it would seem significantly less likely that Trump can win this one than the presidency (estimated at 30% chance). However, presidential elections can swing significantly at any point, so it shouldn't be ruled out (e.g. 1988). Polls can also have errors & biases (1948). A current 6% lead could still be closed.
HRC's double digit lead is down to Low single digits in the last two real clear polls.
Hillary Clinton leads the polls in this state and Tim Kaine is a Senator and former governor of Virginia and mayor of Richmond. As Tip O'Neill says, "All politics is local."
Higher approval rating then Trump in Virgina
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
Polls have been strong for Clinton in Virginia, and the campaign has not bought ads there, suggesting that their internal polling and voter data models show an even stronger lead than public data.

Virginia seems likely to go to Clinton in this race.

updated, multi-model average from NYT Upshot
http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/upshot/presidential-polls-forecast.html?_r=0
Hillary Clinton still leading polls in Virginia by ample margin... zzzzzzzz
Hillary Clinton has a big lead over Donald Trump in Virginia, according to a new poll released Tuesday, which shows the Democratic nominee with a 16-point advantage in the state (CNN)
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

Clinton is currently up 7.1 based on Polling Averages. Fivethirtyeight gives Clinton an 88% chance of winning based on Polls only, 83.9% on polls plus. Went for Obama by substantial margins twice. Tim Kaine is sitting senator from Virginia and former governor. Trump seems to be backing off some of his more outlandish and incendiary statements and policies under new leadership, which may help his chances. However, the damage is most likely done. I put the chances as higher than fivethirtyeights polls plus, which is based on economic and historical data. I think this slightly underestimates Clinton's chances based on the unprecedented campaign and likability polling of Donald Trump and a possible shift in colors based on current polling and the election margins of Obama, despite George W. Bush receiving well over 50% of the vote in both of his elections. Also, Tim Kaine's selection as VP will help here above what is projected in the polls plus forecast. I put Clinton's chances slightly below current polling because of Trump's recent campaign shakeup and recent backtracking on statements that demonstrate a possible shift in tone of his campaign.
Trump in a hole he can't emerge from

The last statewide elections were close in spite of predictions of easy Democratic wins. The fact they went to Democrats has fostered the impression that Virginia is now a blue state. Trump v. Clinton is a better match-up than the last gubernatorial and senate races were for the Republicans.
Her Vice Presidential running mate will help her carry the state.

Hillary Clinton is ahead of Donald Trump in another swing state, according to a new poll, holding a wide lead over the GOP presidential nominee in Virginia. Clinton beats Trump among registered voters there, 52% to 38%, and retains her edge among likely voters, 51% to 43%, the new poll from the Washington Post released Tuesday reports (CNN)
Virginia has been trending blue anyway now former VA Gov Tim Kaine is on the ticket.
I think Hillary appeals to the people of Virginia. Can't see them wanting a radical like Trump.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
Trump has shown anot inability to correct course, but we are talking Virginia.  Lastly, they've swung towards blue in the past 2 elections.  That trend will continue.
Virginia's a purple state, strong headwinds do not go in Trump's favor.

M. Petits-Doigts will carry a few counties in Southside, but even along the I-81 corridor he's in trouble, and he has no chance in the DC suburbs and probably not around Richmond.   Being impulsive, ignorant, and arrogant turns out not to be helpful with the military enclaves around Norfolk--they are actual conservatives, unlike him, and are not anxious to get killed over an insult to his hand size; and they are quite clear about his naivete around NATO and his pal Putin and whatnot.  En fin, he has virtually no chance in Virginia.

demographics shifted towards democrats. 
Polls say Hillary
state voting is heavily correlated with other states, so if trump wins Virginia he wins the elections. 
its to late for someone else,
trump wont give up he is to selfabsorbed for this
he will become more extremistic when election day comes closer with him behind in the polls. witch is bad tactic
Once again making a prediction I don't believe in, but my method is to bet big on Predictwise. http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-president-winner
The margin of victory for Hillary in Virginia will be a bit  slim but the demographic of  college educated  percentage and  progressive republicans will give Hillary an edge.

Dem population increasing by migration from NE.  Desire to continue O.s policy.  The dream Dems (or any other body) can increase paying work.  Trump's clutsy manner of presenting himself and his wishes for policy. Women voting for a woman.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
Using the current 538 forecast as my initial prior: http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/?ex_cid=rrpromo.

Trump's candidacy was legitimized by the media and now he has destroyed his legitimacy only because he never had any except what the media granted him.  The MSM have a lot to answer for.  Trump represents a group with legitimate grievances but burdened by their own ignorance and racism.  Virginia's Tim Kaine is the VP candidate and that fairly well guarantees that the majority of Virginia, which is in the urbanized and suburbanized DC metro area, will vote Democratic.

I am taking into consideration that Hillary is very likely to win VA given Kaine's presence, but in the scenarios where she doesn't, it is more likely that a replacement candidate for Trump has more success than Trump himself.  The ballot deadline in VA appears to be 9/9/2016, meaning that there is still more than a month to replace Trump if he flames out, which increases the likelihood that there will be a replacement who can win.

Last presidential elections it was 51,16% Democrat.
Presidential election polls 2016 show Clinton on top.

While Obama won the last two by fairly narrow margins (best was 4%) I believe the Trump turnout card and Hillary negatives will bring VA back to where its been historically pre-obama.  Plus Obama had a huge impact on black (democratic) voters. while Hillary will win the black vote she is unlikely to impact the voter turnout the way Obama did.
After DT answer to the fallen solder's father and mother. No matter Muslem or not some will not forgive DT reaction..

after being stationed at Andrews and living in D.C. it was obvious that, in general, people in the DC region have a higher "political IQ" than the average blue collar average joe.  There opinions were often times based on a more in depth look at the issues and therefore I have to believe that the abundance of comments that D.T. makes that illustrate his shallow understanding of issues will have more of an impact.
Clinton is considered better for government spending and VP choice is from VA although Trump's promises of high infrastructure spending will make this a close contest.

OK, we are now post conventions.  Trump has been trump, pulls have changed.  They should settle in a few weeks, but for now, remaining at 80% Hillary.  538 is around 75%, Upshot is 73%.  Continuing to rely on Trump being an idiot.  Waiting for more data.
Virginia is purple and Trump is shooting himself and out-of-control
Obama carried Virginia, and now the state's own Tim Kaine is Hillary Clinton's running mate.

Clinton's selection of Virginia Senator Tim Kaine for her Vice Presidential running mate was intended to increase the Democratic turnout in Virginia.  Virginia Governor Terry McAuliffe, a Democrat, has restored the voting rights of ~200,000 felons - also likely increasing the Democrat vote turnout in Virginia.  Having just been told by the Virginia Supreme Court that he can only grant voting rights via clemency on a case by case basis, Governor McAuliffe has stated that he will sign the necessary estimated 385 clemency orders a day to restore felons' voting rights- per the NY Times July 26 article.  The combination of Kaine's and McAuliffe's positions adds to the facts that in 2012, Virginia voted Democratic; in 2008, Virginia voted Democratic, and the Democratic areas of Northern Virginia continue to increase population.   On the other hand, traditionally more conservative southern Virginia is likely to stay Republican.  The likelihood is that Virginia will narrowly vote for Clinton.
selection of Kain should insulate clinto from serious competition in this traditional swing state
The V.P. candidate and the entrenched Democratic Party in the DC area will carry the state for Hillary.
In a state-wide elections Virginia votes consistently  for Democrats.

Virginia has been slowly turning blue over the last 8 years. With a large professional class of voters 
In the Washington suburbs Hillary will easily carry northern Virginia. Those number will overcome the the rural parts of the states
Clinton is win in Virginia because Tim Kaine will deliver the state for her.

PredictWise's estimate of odds. Consensus is 80.5%, fairly similar.
http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-president-winner

Starting with 538 blog 70% for Hillary, and bumping it up 10%.  Two reasons - Hillary has much more infrastructure (donations and workers), and Hillary has a dozen power democrats she can call on, Donald has ... Duck Dynasty?  Interesting race.
The Vice President is from Virginia and it was one by Obama easily.
Trump might have dropped out by election night.
538 has it at 60-40. That doesn't factor in Kaine as VP candidate or the GOTV efforts, which will benefit Democrats by 1-2% in battleground states.
Votes for safety as well as anger votes will off set D.C. area government employees and beneficiaries vote.

POLLS:
Most polls show Hilllary Clinton leading so far: http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/va/virginia_trump_vs_clinton-5542.html Her vice presidential pick, Gov Tim Kaine, will help.   RECENT PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS:
In 2012, Barack Obama received 51.16% of the vote, compared to Mitt Romney's 47.28%
In 2008, Obama won Virginia by 6.3%.  2016 PRIMARIES:
In terms of the Democratic primary, Hillary won the state with 64.3% (503,358 votes) while Bernie received 35.2% (275,507) Trump won the Republican primary with 34.7% (355,960) but was closely trailed by Marco Rubio who got 31.9%
(327,042); Ted Cruz received 16.9% (173,193), Kasich 9.4% (96,519) and Carson 5.9% (60,093) Given these recent results, and given that Trump is still failing at mounting a comprehensive campaign operation on the state, I'm going to give Hillary ample advantage on this one.

Based on the NY Times Upshot average for models reporting a percentage.
http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/upshot/presidential-polls-forecast.html
Real Clear Politics polls show a post convention improvement in HRC numbers.

The Northern Virginia (D.C. suburban) vote consists heavily of government employees and contractors and their wives and families.  Same for the area around Richmond.  These people are overwhelmingly not in favour of an erratic blowhard for president, and even the ones who have traditionally voted R will switch or abstain.   Over by Norfolk there are more military types.  You might expect them to be more conservative, and they are, but they are not interested in having an erratic blowhard for CinC, who could send them God Nose Ware to do God Nose Watt because somebody's tweet expressed doubt about his finger size.  They will switch or vote Libertarian, or more likely, abstain.  That leaves Southside, which is heavily Trump country.   That leaves Southside.  They are True Believers in whatever the Trump message of the moment is, but there aren't enough of them to swing the state R.  They get interviewed a lot on t.v. because they say colourful stuff, but each of them still only gets one vote.  As a general matter, it is well to disregard state-level polls until around the end of September, and of course to disregard national popular-vote polls at all times, since the popular vote doesn't matter in the presidentials.
